entry.title: How I made this site
entry.summary: Today I'm going to tell you how I quickly made this website…
entry.content:
Today I'm going to tell you how I quickly made this website using Publii and hosted it for free on GitHub Pages.

My goal was to quickly develop and host a simple, yet good-looking portfolio\blog site for free. After some research I found Publii - a no-database CMS, that allows to easily upload to GitHub Pages for a free hosting. And it features a nice set of free themes!

Publii is a free desktop app that allows you to edit and manage your site's content using intuitive user interface. No html\css knowledge required.

(Although, I do know how build sites from scratch, I think using a ready solution is smarter than hand-crafting your site from scratch.)

That's it. I could go more in-depth about setting it up, but there are already plenty of guides on it.

entry.title: MonsterCraft2 - making sequels is hard
entry.summary: After good reception of MonsterCraft it was obvious that we should release…
entry.content:
After good reception of MonsterCraft it was obvious that we should release a sequel. Turns out, making a good sequel is not as easy as it seems - we had to add new stuff without overcomplicating things.

Here is a list of things we decided to do in the sequel:

  • Added in a third race - demons. Demons can't be crafted, but player can capture and use them later in the game.
  • Added an ability to buy armor for your units. So now each unit has 3 tiers: no armor, light armor, heavy armor.
  • Added spells - a way for a player to take part in fights.
  • Made a game longer by adding more worlds\levels.
  • Added a boss in the end of each world. Final boss also tricky and required smart use of spells to win.
  • Added achievements.

entry.title: Crimson Squad - Trying to make a bigger game
entry.summary: This one took a while to finish. Still working with the same…
entry.content:
This one took a while to finish. Still working with the same team I made Cortex Fortress and MonsterCraft with, we decided to make something more complex: a top-down shooter with a lot of levels, enemy types, weapons, perks, bosses etc.

Our 3d artist rendered 3d models and effects into images so we could simulate 3d in flash. It looked great, but had me struggle a lot with performance: it was the first time I had to spend a lot of time optimizing the game. And I loved that challenge. For example, I had to find a way to draw blood into the ground texture, so it doesn't take extra memory and the game runs smooth.

entry.title: Monster Craft - A good idea is worth a lot
entry.summary: So I was hanging out with my best friend and were brainstoring game…
entry.content:
So I was hanging out with my best friend and were brainstoring game ideas. We weren't planning to develop one together - we just enjoyed discussing interesting game ideas.

That day we came up with the idea of MonsterCraft:

  • Take a basic combination logic: A+B=C and use it to craft units. Make the result logical: robot+robot = bigger robot, zombie+zombie = big zombie, robot+zombie = cyborg zombie!

I described the idea to the team I made Cortex Fortress with and we developed the game fairly quickly.

It was quite successful: we got a lot of good reviews and people started making walthroughs and letsplays of MonsterCraft on youtube. One of those videos got 7 million views:

Later we started to notice reskinned versions of our game on the web and android versions on Google Play Store:

We contacted Google to take those down. Eventually they did take down some of those, but new ones kept popping up and we gave up. I'd say proudly I accepted this as a sign of success and popularity.

If you want, you play MonsterCraft online on ArmorGames.

entry.title: Cortex Fortress - Developing together
entry.summary: After releasing my first game - BrainDef, I got my first fan!…
entry.content:
After releasing my first game - BrainDef, I got my first fan!

It was not just an ordinary fan, it was a guy, experienced in making 2d and 3d art for games. He offered to join me and make another game for a 50\50 profits split when it goes live. I was so hyped back then! Later on he also invited his friend into our little team, who took care of SFX and music.

Those people helped me gain confidence and motivation to release my games faster and brought the quality level of my games way up.

entry.title: BrainDef - My first game
entry.summary: Back in 2012, after reading a lot of success stories on flashgamedev.ru I…
entry.content:
Back in 2012, after reading a lot of success stories on flashgamedev.ru I decided to try creating a game myself.

This was my first experience of programming. I used Adobe Flash (which uses ActionScript3 as a scripting language). I used this amazing tutorial to learn how to create a basic shooter game in Flash, and then just remixed it a little.

In this game you can find references to my favourite games of the time: Team Fortress 2, C&C, Wormix.

You can play BrainDef on Kongregate.

entry.title: Animated banners - a first hobby job -
entry.summary: On my first year of university I started earning some pocket money as a…
entry.content:
On my first year of university I started earning some pocket money as a freelancer. It wasn't much, but it was fun. I always wanted to become an animator - and this job was basically about animating adverisement banners in Adobe Flash.

Here are some examples of those banners. For more you can look into my fl.ru profile.

 

The more I used Adobe Flash, the more creative I started getting. I found out that you can also do interactive stuff in flash, so I dived into simple scripting and created this: a plate-clock that shows real time, with a silly secret that you could find if you drag a knife or a fork with your mouse!

Here are some screenshots for those, who can't use flash in their browser:

  

This was an incredible experience and helped me learn basics of animation and scripting, which I later used to develop flash games.
